g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: Chain of Responsibility (=object oriented linked list) Pass a...
g.text: Chain of Responsibility (=object oriented linked list)Pass a request along a ‘chained’ group of objects without direct coupling between sender and receiver.

g.title: Rectangle.119
g.desc: Multiple objects may handle a request
g.text: Multiple objects may handle a request

g.title: Folded Corner.205
g.desc: The Chain Of Responsibility pattern compliments Open Closed P...

g.text: The Chain Of Responsibility pattern compliments Open Closed Principle. OCP is supported by the Dependency Inversion Principle. A concrete Handler follows the Handler abstraction. Via Dependency injection Handlers are being injected into each other. This makes both sender and receiver dependent on an abstraction and not their details. This adds flexibility to extend and change. New ‘Handlers’ can be added, removed or re-order within the chain without modifying existing code. Not modifying existing code adds stability in production and test code.

g.title: Rectangle.210
g.desc: The order, type and set of objects to handle a request is unk...
g.text: The order, type and set of objects to handle a request is unknown

g.title: Folded Corner.216
g.desc: The Chain of Responsibility pattern supports unfamiliarity be...

g.text: The Chain of Responsibility pattern supports unfamiliarity between sender and receiver. This provides the advantage to ‘swap’, re-order or add ‘handlers’ within the chain of objects. This flexibility makes it possible to modify the chain dynamically during runtime instead of defining it statically during compile time.

g.title: Folded Corner.196
g.desc: The Chain of Responsibility provides a lot of flexibility in ...

g.text: The Chain of Responsibility provides a lot of flexibility in ‘chaining up’ multiple Handlers. However, this comes with a price. Namely, the Single Responsibility Principle can be ‘over-done’. The Chain of Responsibility insists that multiple Handler objects are created. All containing a ‘bit’ of ‘chain’ logic. It makes readability, navigability & debuggability of the code harder, because the logic is scattered. This disadvantage can be outweighed by the flexibility the pattern brings in ordering, adding/removing and reusing Handlers.

g.title: Folded Corner.235
g.desc: The Chain of Responsibility links multiple objects by means o...

g.text: The Chain of Responsibility links multiple objects by means of dependency injection. The Base Handler contains default implementation to move to the next handler in the chain. When a request comes in a Handler tries to process it and/or passes it along the chain. The end of the chain is often indicated by not specifying a next handler. E.g. a help option in the UI could be displayed via a Button element. Incase the Button does not specify this help ‘behavior’ it passes the request to its parent: Dialog. If the Dialog cannot handle it, then it will be passed to the Application.

g.title: Folded Corner.239
g.desc: The Chain Of Responsibility compliments the Single Responsibi...

g.text: The Chain Of Responsibility compliments the Single Responsibility pattern. E.g. a request, first handled by the client via a high cyclomatic function that contains a bunch of if-else statements, can now be decomposed into multiple Handler objects. This increases testability, stability and reusability of the code. Testability, because each Handler can be tested isolated in a ‘small’ problem window. Stability, the risk of breaking something unrelated to the change becomes smaller. Reusability, handlers can be re-used in the same or in a different chain.

g.title: Folded Corner.244
g.desc: If-else structures can be seen as a Chain Of Responsibilities...

g.text: If-else structures can be seen as a Chain Of Responsibilities. Actions will be executed if certain conditions are met otherwise the next condition will be ‘tried’. This structure can be decomposed into an object-like structure (=Chain of Responsibility) to gain flexibility, reusability and testability.
